learning_outcomes.description: Electronic structure of materials - Comprehend the atomic interaction (atomic bonding) and classes of materials.
Electronic structure of materials - Estimate, from first principles, the elastic modulus of different materials.
Crystal structure of metals - Demonstrate comprehension of the basic structures of crystals and their defects, including dislocations, point defects and interfaces.
Crystal structure of metals - Understand the effects of the defects on mechanical properties.
Crystal structure of metals - Know the basic principle of atomic diffusions in metals.
Mechanical behaviour of materials - Understand the various methods of strengthening (e.g. what makes some Al alloys stronger and harder than pure Al metal), and how steels can be strengthened.
Mechanical behaviour of materials - Understand the difference of various mechanical properties of metals, such as Young's modulus, yield strength, tensile strength, toughness and ductility.
Phase diagrams, phase transformations and plastic - Interpret binary phase diagrams.
Phase diagrams, phase transformations and plastic - Solve elementary problems on diffusive and diffusionless phase transformations applied to aluminum alloys and steels.
Phase diagrams, phase transformations and plastic - Know the principle and process of heat treatment of metals to improve their mechanical properties.
Phase diagrams, phase transformations and plastic - Understand the mechanisms of plastic deformation and recrystallisation of metals.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Understand the basic principle and process of heat treatment of steels and non-ferrous alloys.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Understand the effects of alloy elements on properties and hardenability of steels.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Understand typical heat treatment processes and the applications of different types of steels.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Comprehend the relationship between precipitation and the mechanical properties of alloys.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Understand the basic knowledge of high entropy alloys, including their design principles and properties.
Heat treatment of metals, and entropy alloy - Contribute to team work in practical groups through data analysis and materials characterization

assessments.task_description:
For each 2-hour lecture, there is a corresponding 2-hour applied class session each week from weeks 1 to 11. Applied class questions will be provided at least one week before the applied class. In the first hour of the applied class, students are to work on the applied class questions and the lecturer and members of the teaching team are available to answer question in the class. In the second hour of the applied class, the first 30 minutes is allocated to the lecturer/members of the teaching team working together with students to answer all the applied class questions. Then, in the last 20 minutes of the applied class, an in-class quiz will be done each week for 10 weeks. Each quiz is worth 2 marks in the total final marks.

Each quiz contains one short answer question that is one of the applied class questions in the same week and two multiple-choice questions. The short answer question is worth 1 mark in the total final mark, and each multiple-choice question is worth 0.5 mark in the total final mark.  Each multiple-choice question has four possible answers, in which only one is correct. Thus, only one answer can be selected. 

Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: All answer sheets are submitted in class at end of the applied class each week.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Age hardening behaviours of AZ91 alloy
assessments.task_description:
The practical will be done in a group; however, an individual report is required. 

If you are applying for an extension to the practical session please ensure you have your correct date and time in your request. You must provide evidence in your request that demonstrates your inability to attend the session at your scheduled date and time. As this is timed assessment, discretionary extensions and extensions based on Student Access Plans (SAPs) will not be accepted for the laboratory session.

Please refer to Blackboard for detailed marking criteria.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
To understand the hardenability of steels and effect of heat treatment process on mechanical properties of steels.

The practical will be done in a group; however, an individual report is required. 

If you are applying for an extension to the practical session please ensure you have your correct date and time in your request. You must provide evidence in your request that demonstrates your inability to attend the session at your scheduled date and time. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
